other_tests.findings: Opening pressure was 25 cm H2O by manometry at the time of surgery. CSF was slightly traumatic (10 leukocytes and 700/mm3 erythrocytes), but protein, glucose, gram stain, and cultures were normal.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Postoperative CT revealed no change in ventricle size. The patientâ€™s headaches did not change with the initial shunt.

other_tests.date: Four months after VP shunt insertion
other_tests.findings: Revealed ventricular enlargement slightly less than that which preceded her shunt.
other_tests.changes_over_time: The patient's headaches began increasing a few days after the head injury.

other_tests.findings: The initial pressure was only 5 cm CSF. CSF was slightly traumatic (8 leukocytes and 9,850/mm3 erythrocytes), but glucose, protein, gram stain, and cultures were normal.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Her clinical condition did not improve unless CSF was siphoned at negative pressures.

other_tests.findings: An adjustable PS Strata II valve was placed on the lowest possible resistance (performance level 0.5: opening pressure 1.5 cm H2O supine, 3 cm H2O standing).
other_tests.changes_over_time: With this treatment, she recovered consciousness and was discharged home with no neurologic deficit. However, her chronic headaches continued as before.

other_tests.date: Five years after placement of the valveless shunt
other_tests.changes_over_time: Her chronic headaches persisted and were treated as migraine.
